persona.name: Stanley Burke

occupation.title: Owner / Operator, Burke Auto & Parts (small independent auto repair + parts resale)
occupation.description: Stanley runs a one-shop auto repair and parts resale business that lives on tight margins. He is responsible for diagnosing vehicles, performing mid-level repairs, sourcing parts (often hunting for the cheapest aftermarket pieces), pricing jobs, dealing with walk-in customers, and handling bookkeeping. He hires one part-time helper who follows his instructions. He publicly criticizes suppliers and competitors on social media and in person, blaming them for poor parts and unfair pricing while disputing his own mistakes or delays. He frequently files complaints or threats of legal action against vendors and occasionally customers, seeing those actions as both a tactic and a deterrent. His shop opens early and closes late — largely because he refuses to delegate — but fluctuating demand and cashflow problems mean he often struggles to cover payroll and bills. He has practical mechanical skill in diagnosing and repairing common car problems (brakes, alternators, basic engine work), but his documentation and customer communication are haphazard and defensive. He knows how to prepare a small-claims case, how to draft terse dispute letters, and how to post incendiary, accusatory reviews that draw attention from locals.

persona.education: High school diploma from a public high school in Buffalo. Completed several non-credit vocational night classes in auto mechanics and small business bookkeeping at a community college. No college degree; attended a short consumer-rights seminar at the local library years ago and reads legal forms and small claims guides frequently.
long_term_goals: Keep the shop open long enough to pay the rent and avoid eviction; anything beyond that is icing he expects will never come.
Expose what he sees as cheating by suppliers and competitors, publicly and legally when possible.
Avoid depending on anyone; be self-reliant enough that he won't have to beg for help.
Leave a small business to his son/daughter only if they can do it his way (rarely trusts they can).
Win a meaningful small-claims case that will humiliate a supplier and validate his grievance.
Make enough to move out of the worst rooming house he lives in, but he believes it will probably not happen.
Make a public stink about local officials who he thinks enable corporate theft.
Keep his pride intact — maintaining the narrative that he tried, even if he expects failure.
Document every perceived wrong and build a dossier to use in future complaints and social-media posts.
Avoid hospital bills by toughing things out; he prefers complaining to doctors rather than following advice.
persona.style: Gruff, bitter, and confrontational. Speech is low, gravelly, and direct; he favors short declarative sentences that come out as accusations. Uses sarcasm and contempt as default registers. Vocabulary is plain and working-class; occasionally slips into profanity when provoked. He speaks with a Western New York / Rust Belt cadence — slow syllables, clipped consonants, occasional local idioms ('on the fritz', 'lemon', 'they're robbin' you blind'). Mannerisms: arms folded, squared shoulders, squinting when listening, leaning on the counter with a hand on his hip, pointing a finger when lecturing. When writing emails or social posts he uses all-caps subject lines, bold complaints, and attached photos of alleged defects. He has a habit of cutting people off mid-sentence, repeating the last thing they said in a mocking tone, and issuing a pointed challenge. Clothes: faded grease-stained work shirts, heavy denim or canvas pants, scuffed steel-toe boots, baseball cap pulled low. He smells faintly of motor oil, cheap coffee, and cigarette smoke. He believes 'manners' are overrated unless they help him win an argument or a case; politeness is transactional. In customer interactions he alternates between brusque efficiency for those he tolerates and long, loud public chastisements for those he believes have cheated him or others.

traits: Misanthropic: actively hostile and resentful toward strangers and groups he perceives as self-serving.
Hypercritical: constantly points out faults in others, suppliers, and institutions without offering cooperative solutions.
Contrarian: dismisses improvements or positive news reflexively; tends to disagree even when evidence suggests otherwise.
Pessimistic / catastrophizing: magnifies small setbacks into existential catastrophes for himself and the shop.
Vindictive: holds grudges for years and seeks small retributive actions like bad reviews, complaints, or lawsuits.
Distrustful: assumes others have hidden motives, especially 'elites' and suppliers.
Stubborn: sticks to his positions and methods even when more flexible approaches could help.
Defensive: externalizes blame and reacts angrily to criticism, rarely self-reflective in the moment.
Resourceful in scarcity: skilled at stretching parts and cash, bartering, and finding last-minute solutions.
Performative: likes to stage public complaints to demonstrate moral superiority about being 'cheated' or neglected.

big_five.openness: Low (25/100). Skeptical of new ideas, prefers proven old methods, distrusts 'trendy' solutions.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low-moderate (40/100). Practical on the job and tough about money, but sloppy with paperwork and long-term planning.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate (55/100). Outspoken and loud in public or when arguing, but not warm or sociable; prefers confrontation over small talk.
big_five.agreeableness: Very low (10/100). Suspicious, competitive, uncooperative, frequently hostile in interactions.
big_five.neuroticism: Very high (85/100). Prone to anxiety, resentment, irritability, catastrophizing, and mood swings when stressed.

interests: Obsessively follows local talk radio and conservative/populist talk shows — knows exact times for callers who complain.
Enjoys watching court TV and small-claims hearing recordings; studies tactics he can adapt.
Regularly reads online forums and community Facebook groups to find complaints to echo.
Collects repair manuals and printed receipts as evidence; keeps a messy folder labeled 'proofs.'
Puts time into social-media posts aimed at shaming suppliers or a 'crooked' competitor.
Likes classic rock (70s/80s) on the shop radio to drown out callers and his own thoughts.
Peruses clearance racks for useful tools rather than buying new name-brand gear.
Watches DIY videos to learn workarounds and corner-cutting fixes he can use cheaply.
Keeps tabs on city council meetings and local zoning news for potential gripes.
Enjoys small-town gossip that confirms his negative beliefs about people in power.
likes: Strong cheap coffee from the diner across the street (black, no nonsense).
Local greasy-spoon breakfasts (eggs over-easy, bacon, rye toast).
Simple, filling foods: meat-and-potatoes, boxed mac and cheese, cheap frozen pizzas.
Inexpensive aftermarket parts that let him keep margins; he praises bargains even while blaming them when they fail.
A tight circle of regular customers who he tolerates and bills without fuss.
Cheap domestic beers on rare slow nights (cans from the corner store).
Significant paperwork or a receipt he can use to build a complaint.
Newspaper clippings that validate his claims about corruption or poor service.
Finding a used part that fits perfectly—small triumphs mean a lot.
The satisfaction of calling out a supplier on the phone and getting a manager to waver.
dislikes: Corporate distributors who 'nickel-and-dime' him on shipping and returns.
Customers who expect perfection and call him a 'rip-off' instead of paying for real work.
Incompetent city inspectors or officials who he believes protect chains over locals.
Young tech entrepreneurs and 'influencers' who he views as privileged and dishonest.
Overly friendly small-talk; sees it as fake and draining.
Warranties that he thinks are worthless cover for corporate negligence.
Employees who ask questions instead of following orders — he sees that as a sign of laziness.
Insurance companies that slow-pay or deny claims.
Health-care bureaucracy and hospital billing systems.
Environmental regulations he views as added cost without visible benefit.
consumer_behavior: Immediately threatens legal action, complains to managers, or posts public reviews when dissatisfied.
Prefers to pay cash, under-the-table deals when possible, or partial installments to minimize paper trails.
Barters services or goods with other small local businesses rather than trusting banks.
Uses small claims court frequently as a tool both for compensation and to make a point.
Prefers local wholesalers who he believes he can intimidate into better prices, but publicly criticizes them regardless.
media_and_technology_preferences: Uses a basic smartphone primarily for social media and taking photos of defective parts.
Posts on a community Facebook page and comments using a harsh, accusatory tone.
Avoids newer platforms he regards as 'silly' (e.g., TikTok), but will post there if he thinks it will attract attention.
Listens to AM talk radio and podcasts about consumer rights and 'how to fight back.'
Prints documents for any dispute and prefers physical proof over digital-only receipts.
customer_service_preferences: Responds best to directness: wants issues acknowledged immediately and compensation offered without elaborate apologies.
Wants to see a clear chain of responsibility — if a supplier dodges, he escalates to a named manager and keeps records.
Assumes good customer service is rare and thus demands it loudly and publicly when it does occur.

beliefs: The system is rigged against small people; elites and corporations manipulate pricing and regulations to crush independent shops.
Suppliers deliberately ship substandard parts to independent businesses to force customers to return to dealership chains.
Local government favors developers and franchises over 'ordinary folks' like him.
Most people are selfish and will exploit any perceived weakness.
The legal system is slow but can be used effectively if you know how to file and document complaints.
Populist rhetoric about 'the elites' is basically correct — politicians and executives lie routinely.
Union leaders are as corrupt as the bosses they negotiate with (respects some workers but distrusts organized leadership).
Media and news outlets often protect corporate interests or avoid reporting on local corruption.
Small businesses are punished by taxes and fines while large corporations get subsidies and favorable treatment.
Banks and credit institutions are predatory and designed to trap people in debt.
Welfare systems attract cheats and give little help to those who actually work hard.
People who talk about 'community' are often hypocrites who only want to be seen as moral.
Customer 'expectations' are unrealistic because of advertising and influencer culture.
Government inspectors are either incompetent or part of the problem; you must document them to hold them accountable.
Climate change is either exaggerated or used as a vehicle for more corporate control — regulations are framed as 'green' but cost local shops.
Healthcare providers charge obscene prices and protect each other; hospitals will always try to bill you for everything.
Taxes are theft when applied to the little guy, but he expects the rich will never pay their fair share.
Advertising and 'brand trust' are manipulative tools to steer consumers toward big-box stores.
Court cases are theater — judges can be persuaded by detailed documentation and community pressure.
Competitors with better capital are untrustworthy or bought off; you can't trust a 'good' review in the age of paid promotions.
Young people who leave town are 'cowards' chasing fantasy careers, and those who stay are stuck in cyclical poverty.
Public officials often give lip service to small businesses while enacting policies that benefit property developers.
Social media is a double-edged sword: a great tool to shame bad actors but also full of liars and trolls.
Police and law enforcement are inconsistent; they help if you have the right connections but ignore small-business thefts unless it's convenient.
Education beyond high school is overrated; it creates entitlement and indebtedness more than practical skill.
People who claim to be 'experts' online are often salespeople; he prefers first-hand evidence and local reputation.
Reputation is everything in a small town; public shaming works better than quiet diplomacy.
Lawsuits are a weapon — worth the time and effort when used to make an example.
Charity is often performative and used by elites to avoid systemic changes.
If you show weakness publicly, you invite predation — always appear tougher than you feel.
Keeping receipts, photos, and notes is the best defense against corporate lies.
If you must choose between principle and survival, survival comes first (he'll posture principled stands but ultimately chooses whatever keeps the shop afloat).
skills: Diagnoses and performs common automotive repairs: brakes, alternators, starter motors, basic engine tune-ups, belt replacements.
Practical troubleshooting: can identify likely failure points quickly by sound and feel.
Basic welding and patching for short-term fixes.
Sourcing and fitting used or aftermarket parts to reduce customer costs and increase margin.
Bartering and negotiating under pressure — aggressive bargaining to squeeze suppliers.
Filing small-claims suits and writing terse demand letters; knows local courthouse procedures.
Documenting complaints: photographs, timestamps, and assembling a 'case file' to present at hearings or online.
Basic bookkeeping: simple ledgers, tracking cash flow, managing petty cash (but not sophisticated accounting).
Public complaint crafting: writing an accusatory social-media post that gets attention from locals.
Street-smarts: reading people quickly, sensing when a customer or supplier is lying or bluffing.
Time management in the short term: juggling multiple vehicles and last-minute walk-ins.
Resource improvisation: fabricating temporary parts when new parts are too expensive or unavailable.
Basic electrical diagnostics for older vehicles; comfortable with analog rather than computer-heavy systems.
Cold-calling suppliers and managers and escalating aggressively to extract concessions.
Managing a small team: sets tasks, enforces rules, and can be authoritative when necessary, though relationships can be brittle.

general: Quick to blame others publicly when things go wrong; posts photos and accusatory captions on the local community page.
Files consumer complaints and small claims cases regularly; keeps a calendar of hearings and vendor responses.
Counts cash and receipts obsessively at the end of every day, muttering about missed margins.
Seldom asks for help; treats offers of assistance with suspicion or as an insult.
Scans incoming invoices immediately for small errors he can exploit as leverage.
Keeps a visible notebook at the counter with scribbled notes and phone numbers of people he's vowed to 'call out.'
Interrupts and lectures customers, often using public chastisement as a control tactic.
Smokes when stressed (outside the shop), despite health concerns; uses smoking breaks as a ritual to cool down.
Keeps a small pile of 'evidence' boxes with returned parts, photos, and complaint forms.
Frequently threatens to escalate disputes to a 'lawyer' although often his actual course is small claims.

morning: Wakes early (around 5:30–6:00 AM), brews very strong black coffee, and reads the local paper and talk-radio transcripts to find fresh grievances.
Opens the shop by 7:00 AM, flips a light on, and does a quick walk-around checking tools and outgoing jobs.
Calls at least one supplier before 8:30 AM to haggle or complain about an invoice or late delivery.
Checks the community Facebook page for overnight posts he can respond to or appropriate people to shame.
workday: Greets regulars with curt acknowledgement and engages new customers with a rapid-fire list of prices and caveats.
Spends large stretches under hoods fixing one vehicle, then walks out to the counter to loudly pronounce a supplier's bad behavior.
Juggles repairs and parts ordering; if a part is delayed he spends time drafting complaint emails and taking photos.
Takes a late-morning cigarette break where he calls a manager at a distributor to escalate an issue.
Posts at least one public complaint during slow shifts, often with a photo and an all-caps headline.
evening: Closes the shop late (often 7–8 PM), counts cash, records notes in his ledger, and pins receipts into his 'cases' folder.
Eats a modest dinner (often leftover or diner food), watches court TV or talk radio, and drafts formal complaint letters.
Sleeps poorly — wakes to rehearse confrontations or legal arguments in his head.
weekend: On slow weekends, he canvasses supply stores and competitor lots to compare prices and collect evidence of 'overcharging.'
Attends council meetings or public hearings to shout at officials when there's an opportunity.
Sometimes meets a small group at the local bar where he rehashes grievances and recruits sympathetic listeners.
Spends hours reorganizing his 'evidence' and preparing for upcoming small-claims dates.

physical: Overweight and carries excess weight around the midsection; sedentary when not working in the shop.
Chronic lower back pain from years of bending and lifting heavy parts; manages pain with over-the-counter meds and occasional ignored prescriptions.
Smoker: a pack a day in stressful periods, fewer when money is tight. Chronic cough and hoarse voice.
Elevated blood pressure; has been warned by clinics but rarely follows up consistently.
Poor dental health: missing molars and irregular dental visits due to cost.
Occasional heavy drinking on slow nights or after particularly frustrating supplier interactions; not daily but problematic.
Limited preventive care due to lack of consistent health insurance; uses community clinic when urgent.
Mild hearing loss in high frequencies from decades of noisy shop environment.
Shortness of breath during exertion and stairs; attributes it to age and the city's air rather than smoking.
Insomnia and poor sleep hygiene: wakes multiple times a night replaying permutations of disputes and worst-case outcomes.
mental: Chronic anger and irritability; experiences frequent mood swings and long periods of resentment.
Signs of depressive thinking: pervasive pessimism, fatalistic outlook, low positive affect.
Anxiety manifested as catastrophizing and hypervigilance about money, reputation, and perceived slights.
High stress levels leading to occasional headaches and stomach complaints.
Reluctant to seek therapy or medication; distrusts mental health professionals and prefers self-management.
Feels vindicated by confirmation of his grievances, which momentarily reduces anxiety but maintains a hostile baseline.
medical_history: No major surgeries recorded, but multiple treated lacerations and abrasions from shop work.
Past minor legal issues — noise complaints, a public disturbance linked to a heated council meeting (no jail time).
Treated at ER once for chest pain two years ago; no conclusive cardiac diagnosis then but follow-up was sparse.
Was prescribed blood pressure medication once but stopped taking it after a few weeks citing side effects and cost.

relationships.name: Monica Burke
relationships.description: Estranged; they split after long periods of arguing about money and his constant public grievances. They share one adult child but barely communicate. Monica occasionally brings legal notices to the shop; she sees him as bitter and unreliable but tolerates him when necessary.

relationships.name: Eli Burke
relationships.description: Works odd jobs and sometimes helps in the shop for cash. Relationship is strained: Stanley expects more toughness and thinks Eli is too soft, while Eli resents the hostile home environment. Eli still relies on the shop for occasional work and won't entirely abandon it.

relationships.name: Rick 'Two-Times' Morales
relationships.description: A competent but younger technician who tolerates Stanley for steady pay and the ability to pick up tricks. He keeps his head down; Stanley barks orders and criticizes often, but Rick recognizes Stanley's mechanical competence.

relationships.name: Janet Dwyer
relationships.description: A woman in her 60s who trusts Stanley despite his attitude; he has fixed her car for years. He treats her differently, showing grudging respect and giving her the occasional discount.

relationships.name: Local small-business circle
relationships.description: A loose group of other small business owners who share complaints about 'the system.' They gather at the same bar, commiserate, and sometimes coordinate public complaints, though trust between them is low.

relationships.name: Frequent adversaries
relationships.description: Multiple vendors have been publicly criticized or sued by Stanley in small claims; there's a running list he keeps and updates. He alternates between negotiating and publicly shaming them.

other_facts: Born and raised in Buffalo, son of a mechanic who owned a small shop; learned hands-on skills in his father's garage from age 12.
As a teenager he dropped competitive sports and got a part-time job at a grocery to help with family expenses — early exposure to scarcity shaped his worldview.
His father taught him to 'never trust a salesman' and that lesson hardened into a general misanthropy.
Opened Burke Auto & Parts at age 31 using a small loan and savings; the shop survived but never grew beyond a single location due to repeated cashflow issues and antagonistic dealings.
Filed his first small-claims suit at 34 against a parts distributor who allegedly sent him faulty brake pads; he won a small refund and the experience turned into a method.
Has lost one court case where his evidence was incomplete; that loss intensified his practice of hoarding receipts and photos.
Was briefly on welfare after a slow winter season when several customers delayed payments; he views that period as humiliating and resents social programs despite having used them.
Once ran a short-lived local campaign for a city advisory committee to push back on zoning changes that favored chains; he lost but used the campaign to publicize grievances.
His memorable social-media tantrum with a photo of a damaged aftermarket alternator went mildly viral locally and resulted in several sympathetic calls and one supplier settlement.
Keeps a small, dented safe behind the counter with petty cash and a few old photos; one is of his father in the original garage.
Has a ritual of making a detailed photo log whenever he installs a part: serial numbers, packing slips, and a short accusatory caption in his notes app.
Collects old National Geographic magazines (ironic for someone skeptical of 'global elites'); keeps them for idle reading and to flip through during slow afternoons.
Has been refused service at one larger supplier for on-going aggressive complaints; he posted the incident online and framed it as proof of collusion.
A neighbor once called the police for a loud argument he had outside the shop after a council meeting; the incident was recorded and circulated by a local blog.
Knows the clerk at the small-claims court by name; they exchange curt pleasantries and paperwork regularly.
Was once arrested for a noise-related disturbance at a public hearing; charges were dropped but the public record remains a badge he regards as a battle scar.
Has a carefully curated list of 'favorites to sue' — vendors and managers who have refused to reverse charges in the past.
Believes that losing a decade ago to a national chain on a pricing war was the turning point that made expansion impossible.
Keeps an old, reliable pickup truck with a cracked windshield and custom repairs—prideful of DIY fixes even if they're ugly.
Has a faded high-school yearbook where he is described as 'practical' — he treasures that as proof his core identity is solid.
Once got a sympathetic local columnist to run an op-ed about 'small shops struggling' after a particularly brazen supplier markup; the column calmed customers for a month.
Uses the shop's bulletin board to post copies of complaint filings and 'wanted' supplier names he believes are untrustworthy.
Has an ongoing feud with a nearby franchise repair shop owner; they occasionally trade passive-aggressive social-media posts that escalate into formal complaints.
Keeps a list of 'never-trust' phrases and tactics in his notebook that he learned from court TV and local bar conversations.
Practices his testimony for hearings aloud in the shop late at night, pacing and reciting dates and invoice numbers until he feels prepared.
Was once forced to accept a buyout from an angry customer to avoid a Yelp tirade; he still resents that and plays it back as an example of how 'they' weaponize reviews.
Has a small lockbox of returned parts labeled with dates and supplier names; he uses them as props when making public accusations.
Has cut ties with siblings over inheritance arguments and long-standing resentments that he still brings up at odd moments.
Is deeply suspicious of any charity drives or community events that involve corporate sponsorship, assuming ulterior motives.
Keeps a list of people he thinks 'owe him' — a combination of customers who didn't pay on time and suppliers who under-delivered; he revisits the list regularly.
When feeling especially vindictive, he will draft a letter to the editor calling out perceived corruption or favoritism in local government.
Keeps a worn pocket Bible in the truck as a cultural artifact from his childhood; he doesn't necessarily internalize its messages but uses it to justify his identity as someone who 'endures.'
Once turned away from a bank loan renewal because of a late tax bill; that denial is a formative grievance he references often.
Has a scrawled map of local competitor parking lots and supplier distribution centers in a back drawer — part data collection, part obsession.
Writes down the names of suppliers and managers with dates of poor service, and circles repeat offenders in red ink as a ritual of accountability.
